newsitem.title: TURKEY: More U.S.-sponsored Kurds to leave Iraq for Guam.
newsitem.headline: More U.S.-sponsored Kurds to leave Iraq for Guam.

text.p: Hundreds of Kurds who worked for U.S.-affiliated organisations will be evacuated to Turkey from Iraq on Saturday after the latest fighting in the volatile region, Turkish border officials said.
"They should cross around lunchtime today. They will eventually go to (the Pacific island of) Guam," he said. The official put the total number of evacuees, including family members, at 730.

The U.S. evacuated more than 2,000 Kurds, including family, who had worked for them as drivers, translators, guides, computer operators and reportedly even as spies, after Baghdad intervened in inter-Kurdish fighting last month.
Those Kurds were taken to Turkey in buses and then by plane to Guam.

Fighting between two rival Kurdish factions erupted again last week when the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK) tried to take back territory it lost last month to the Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP).

In late August the KDP captured the regional capital of Arbil with backing from Iraqi government troops and then took control of the whole of the Kurdish north. Baghdad is not believed to be involved this time.
